This thesis provides methodological development within the scope of cancer bioinformatics, focusing on analysis of data from high-throughput genomic experiments to support the characterization of the molecular basis and the investigation of mechanisms underlying cancer formation. The objectives are: 1) to provide an algorithm for rapid detection and quantification of microRNAs, 2) to develop a software pipeline for analysis and visualization of CpG-site methylation in a case-control setting, and 3) to apply previously developed genomic analysis in order to investigate the cellular and molecular origin of rhabdomyosarcoma.

This thesis will help to provide methodological tools that will enable faster and efficient coral genomic data generation needed for testing hypothesis of co-evolution, co-diversification and functioning in the coral holobiont.
